user_message:
Target function code is:
```c
void UtAssert_DoTestSegmentReport(const char *SegmentName, const UtAssert_TestCounter_t *TestCounters)
{
    char ReportBuffer[144];

    snprintf(ReportBuffer, sizeof(ReportBuffer),
             "%-22s ABORT::%-4u  WARN::%-4u  FLOW::%-4u  DEBUG::%-4u  N/A::%-4u",
             "",
             (unsigned int)TestCounters->CaseCount[UTASSERT_CASETYPE_ABORT],
             (unsigned int)TestCounters->CaseCount[UTASSERT_CASETYPE_WARN],
             (unsigned int)TestCounters->CaseCount[UTASSERT_CASETYPE_FLOW],
             (unsigned int)TestCounters->CaseCount[UTASSERT_CASETYPE_DEBUG],
             (unsigned int)TestCounters->CaseCount[UTASSERT_CASETYPE_NA]);

    UT_BSP_DoText(UTASSERT_CASETYPE_INFO, ReportBuffer);

    snprintf(ReportBuffer, sizeof(ReportBuffer),
             "%02u %-20s TOTAL::%-4u  PASS::%-4u  FAIL::%-4u  MIR::%-4u  TSF::%-4u  TTF::%-4u",
             (unsigned int)TestCounters->TestSegmentCount, SegmentName, (unsigned int)TestCounters->TotalTestCases,
             (unsigned int)TestCounters->CaseCount[UTASSERT_CASETYPE_PASS],
             (unsigned int)TestCounters->CaseCount[UTASSERT_CASETYPE_FAILURE],
             (unsigned int)TestCounters->CaseCount[UTASSERT_CASETYPE_MIR],
             (unsigned int)TestCounters->CaseCount[UTASSERT_CASETYPE_TSF],
             (unsigned int)TestCounters->CaseCount[UTASSERT_CASETYPE_TTF]);

    UT_BSP_DoText(UTASSERT_CASETYPE_END, ReportBuffer);
}
```

List additional symbols that are required to analyze the target function to determine if the target function code violates the following MISRA C rule:
Language extensions should not be used. You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
The list will be included in the prompt for the next agent, so be concise and clear.
Explain why each symbol is required in the analysis of the target function for the MISRA C rule.
explanation:
- UtAssert_TestCounter_t: The function dereferences TestCounters and indexes CaseCount. The type definition may use compiler extensions (anonymous structures/unions, bit‑fields with implementation behavior, packed/packed attribute, flexible array members in nonstandard ways). Need the full type to verify only standard language constructs are used.
- UT_BSP_DoText: This symbol is called from the function. It may be a macro or function declared with compiler extensions (inline assembly, GCC __attribute__ annotations, variadic macros, nonstandard calling conventions). Its definition/prototype is required to ensure no language extensions are used in its declaration/expansion.
- UTASSERT_CASETYPE_* (ABORT, WARN, FLOW, DEBUG, N/A, INFO, END, PASS, FAILURE, MIR, TSF, TTF): These identifiers are used as array indices and arguments. They may be macros (possibly using token‑pasting, statement expressions, or other extensions) or nonstandard enum definitions. Their actual definitions are needed to confirm they are standard enum/const macros and do not rely on compiler extensions.
- snprintf (stdio prototype): Although from the standard library, some platforms provide nonstandard variants or macro wrappers. The actual prototype/inclusion (stdio.h) should be confirmed to ensure no platform/compiler extension (nonstandard signature, macro wrapper) is being used.

Providing these symbol definitions lets the next analyzer determine whether any of the referenced types, macros, or called‑function declarations/expansions introduce language extensions that would violate the MISRA rule.
